It's quite unfortunate that getting the number of constructors is linear in the same number.             case dataCons of
                DataVariant cons -> (,,) (length cons) (\k -> CPVariant scrutTCon (fst (cons !! k)) wildcard)

comments.body:
Because of `lookupWithIndex`, this whole process is linear in the number of constructors *and* linear in the number of alternatives, meaning it's quadratic in the number of constructors for any match that doesn't use a default branch. That sounds problematic... ðŸ˜¢ 

It's probably worth it to construct a `Map` for these lookups, something like

```Haskell
Map.fromList [(name, (rank, type)) | (rank, (name, type)) <- zip (0 ..) cons]
```

even if it's just in `typeOfAltsVariant` and `typeOfAltsEnum`.

Yeah, I agree that this is bad and needs fixing. Since the issue is not coming from this change but has been there before, I'm inclined to fix it in a separate PR. I would fix this in a more general fishing and replace
```haskell
data DataCons
  = DataRecord  ![(FieldName, Type)]
  | DataVariant ![(VariantConName, Type)]
  | DataEnum ![VariantConName]
```
by
```haskell
data DataCons
  = DataRecord  !(Vector (FieldName, Type)) !(Map FieldName Int)
  | DataVariant !(Vector (VariantConName, Type)) !(Map VariantConName Int)
  | DataEnum !(Vector VariantConName) !(Map VariantConName Int)
```
At least for records and variants we have lots of linear lookups all over the type checker. Since values of type `DataCons` are read way more often than they are written, this sort of caching seems reasonable to me. Or do you think that's a bad idea?
That seems reasonable, though I'd prefer these "association vector, index map" pairs were wrapped up in a generic type (similar to Data.NameMap) that maintains the invariant we want.
Yeah, that's what I was planning to do. I'll take care of it. ðŸ˜„
